title: Diaphragmatic Endometriosis
author: Alyson Powell Key

sections.heading: What Is Diaphragmatic Endometriosis?
content: Endometriosis is a painful and sometimes lifelong condition where tissue similar to the tissue that lines your uterus is found outside of the uterus .
It happens in two general areas of your body:

Most people with this condition will have it in their pelvis, but researchers have found that around 12% have it outside the pelvis. One rare type is when the condition spreads to your diaphragm -- the muscle that helps you breathe in and out.
bullets: Inside of your pelvis (pelvic endometriosis)
Outside of your pelvis (extrapelvic endometriosis)

content_blocks.text: Endometriosis is a painful and sometimes lifelong condition where tissue similar to the tissue that lines your uterus is found outside of the uterus .
It happens in two general areas of your body:
associated_bullets: Inside of your pelvis (pelvic endometriosis)
Outside of your pelvis (extrapelvic endometriosis)

content_blocks.text: Most people with this condition will have it in their pelvis, but researchers have found that around 12% have it outside the pelvis. One rare type is when the condition spreads to your diaphragm -- the muscle that helps you breathe in and out.

sections.heading: Diaphragmatic Endometriosis Causes
content: Medical experts aren’t sure of the exact cause of endometriosis . Some reasons include:
bullets: Backward flow of menstrual blood . With this condition, called retrograde menstruation, blood and endometrial cells flow back through your fallopian tubes and into your pelvis instead of out of your body. These cells, which cause endometriosis, can also reach your diaphragm and stick there.
Cell movement. Your blood vessels or lymphatic system may carry endometrial cells to other parts of your body.

Cell changes. Hormones or immune issues could change the cells that line the inside of your abdomen (peritoneal cells), or other cells at their earliest stages of development, into endometrial-like cells.
Immune system problems. Your immune system may not be able to spot and destroy endometrial-like tissue that grows outside of your uterus.

content_blocks.text: Medical experts aren’t sure of the exact cause of endometriosis . Some reasons include:
associated_bullets: Backward flow of menstrual blood . With this condition, called retrograde menstruation, blood and endometrial cells flow back through your fallopian tubes and into your pelvis instead of out of your body. These cells, which cause endometriosis, can also reach your diaphragm and stick there.
Cell movement. Your blood vessels or lymphatic system may carry endometrial cells to other parts of your body.

Cell changes. Hormones or immune issues could change the cells that line the inside of your abdomen (peritoneal cells), or other cells at their earliest stages of development, into endometrial-like cells.
Immune system problems. Your immune system may not be able to spot and destroy endometrial-like tissue that grows outside of your uterus.

sections.heading: Diaphragmatic Endometriosis Symptoms
content: It’s common not to feel any symptoms with diaphragmatic endometriosis. Researchers think that 70% of people with this condition won’t have any. If you do have symptoms, they can include:

Pain symptoms may happen around your menstrual period but can crop up at any time. Around 95% of endometriosis lesions develop on the right side of your diaphragm, causing pain on that side of your body. Your level of pain depends on where in your body lesions are located and how deep they are.
bullets: Pain in your: Chest Upper abdomen on your right side Shoulder Lower ribs
Pain when you breathe
Feeling sick to your stomach or throwing up ( nausea or vomiting)

sections.heading: Diaphragmatic Endometriosis Diagnosis
content: Many people live with diaphragmatic endometriosis for a long time without a diagnosis -- often until their mid-to-late 30s. This is later in life than people with more common forms of the condition.

Many doctors may only look for endometriosis in your pelvis. They may miss hidden lesions in your diaphragm. They also sometimes discover endometriosis in your diaphragm by accident, or wrongly diagnose it as a different disease.

content_blocks.text: Many people live with diaphragmatic endometriosis for a long time without a diagnosis -- often until their mid-to-late 30s. This is later in life than people with more common forms of the condition.

Many doctors may only look for endometriosis in your pelvis. They may miss hidden lesions in your diaphragm. They also sometimes discover endometriosis in your diaphragm by accident, or wrongly diagnose it as a different disease.

content: Some researchers now suggest that doctors check all people with pelvic endometriosis symptoms for the condition in the diaphragm as well. They estimate that if you have one form of the disease, there’s a 50%-90% chance that you’ll also have the other.
It often takes a thorough doctor to suspect endometriosis of the diaphragm. They’ll use imaging tests to find out more, including:
If you have this type of endometriosis, doctors will usually find lesions on your diaphragm or behind your liver.
bullets: CT scan. This fast and painless test uses special X-ray equipment to look at abnormal areas inside of your chest closely.
MRI . This test uses a magnetic field and radio waves to create detailed images of your organs and tissues. An MRI may show more detail than a CT scan.

MRI . This test uses a magnetic field and radio waves to create detailed images of your organs and tissues. An MRI may show more detail than a CT scan.

content_blocks.text: If you have this type of endometriosis, doctors will usually find lesions on your diaphragm or behind your liver.

sections.heading: Diaphragmatic Endometriosis Treatment
content: There are two main treatments for this condition: medication and surgery.
bullets: Hormone treatment. If you don’t plan to have children, your doctor will likely suggest medicine to treat your endometriosis. Birth control pills or patches help control hormones that cause endometrial tissue to build up every month. And drugs called GnRH antagonists lower your estrogen and stop your period, which shrinks endometrial tissue. Your doctor could also prescribe pain medication along with hormone therapy.
Surgery. An operation to remove lesions is best for people who have ongoing pain even after taking medication. There is a risk of damage to your diaphragm, lungs, heart, or nerves.

content_blocks.text: There are two main treatments for this condition: medication and surgery.

Birth control pills or patches help control hormones that cause endometrial tissue to build up every month. And drugs called GnRH antagonists lower your estrogen and stop your period, which shrinks endometrial tissue. Your doctor could also prescribe pain medication along with hormone therapy.
Surgery. An operation to remove lesions is best for people who have ongoing pain even after taking medication. There is a risk of damage to your diaphragm, lungs, heart, or nerves.

sections.heading: Diaphragmatic Endometriosis Outlook
content: While hormone therapy can lower your pain, it isn’t a cure for endometriosis. There’s a chance that your symptoms could come back if you stop treatment.

With a skilled medical team, surgery is safe and works for most people to relieve endometriosis pain. There’s a low chance of problems during or after surgery, or that your symptoms will come back. Some types of surgery offer a shorter hospital stay than others, and you can go back to your regular activity sooner.

With a skilled medical team, surgery is safe and works for most people to relieve endometriosis pain. There’s a low chance of problems during or after surgery, or that your symptoms will come back. Some types of surgery offer a shorter hospital stay than others, and you can go back to your regular activity sooner.

sources: Journal of the Turkish-German Gynecological Association: “Thoracic and diaphragmatic endometriosis: Single-institution experience using novel, broadened diagnostic criteria.”
International Journal of Fertility & Sterility: “Endometriosis of Diaphragm: A Case Report.”
Human Reproduction : “Asymmetry in distribution of diaphragmatic endometriotic lesions: evidence in favour of the menstrual reflux theory.”
Journal of obstetrics and gynaecology : “Diaphragmatic endometriosis minimally invasive treatment: a feasible and effective approach.”
meta_description: Most of the time endometriosis affects your pelvis, but sometimes it spreads to other areas of your body like your diaphragm. What are the symptoms when this happens, and how do you treat it?
